Type aliases

Alpha

Alpha: number[]
brief

Alpha vector which can be of any size. This is essentially a renaming in order to match this publication

AlphaParameters

AlphaParameters: { mapping?: alphaMapping; max: number[]; min: number[] }
brief

Parameters for defining Alpha, i.e., the min/max of each value as well as an optional alphaMapping which allows to convert a user-defined parameter space to the global one. For stochastic smulation, parameters will be sampled in these ranges.

example
// First parameters is theta in [0°, 180°]
// Second parameter is stress ratio in [0, 3]
const parameters = { 
    mapping: new SimpleAndersonMapping,
    min: [  0, 0],
    max: [180, 3]
}

Type declaration

  • Optional mapping?: alphaMapping
  • max: number[]
  • min: number[]

InversionModel

InversionModel: { alpha: AlphaParameters; data: Data[]; onMessage?: Function; onProgress?: Function }
brief

Parameters for the inversion, which are the measured and the calculated data along with their associated cost function and weight. The AlphaParameters has to be provided as well with the number of iterations for the inversion algorithm.

Type declaration

  • alpha: AlphaParameters

    The parameter space to use with the mapping if necessary

  • data: Data[]

    All the provided Data to constrain the inversion

  • Optional onMessage?: Function

    The messages callback

  • Optional onProgress?: Function

    The progression callback for the method of inversion (monte-carlo, mcmc, Bees, ...)

InversionResult

InversionResult: { alpha: number[]; cost: number; fit: number; user: number[] }
brief

The inversion solution

Type declaration

  • alpha: number[]

    The inverted Alpha parameters

  • cost: number

    The best cost from inversion in [0, 1]. A value close to zero means a "good" inversion. A value close to one means the opposite.

  • fit: number

    The best fit in %. The fit is related to cost by: fit = 100(1-cost)

  • user: number[]

    The corresponding inverted user parameters (inverse mapping). If the mapping was not provided, then user will be equal to alpha

Geology Functions

generateConjugates

  • generateConjugates(__namedParameters: { friction: number; projected?: boolean; stress: Serie }): { n1: Serie; n2: Serie } | Serie

  • Generate from stress data either 2 series representing the normals of the conjugate planes, or one serie if projected = true (direction of S2). For the former case, the friction angle is used. For the later, friction angle is irrelevant.

    example
    const conjugates = geop.generateConjugates({ // {n1: Serie, n2: Serie}
     stress: computedStressSerie,
     friction: 30,
     projected: false
})
console.log( conjugates.n1, conjugates.n2 )

const conjugate = geop.generateConjugates({ // Serie
     stress: computedStressSerie,
     friction: 30,
     projected: true
})
console.log( conjugate )
    see

    ConjugateData

    Parameters

    • __namedParameters: { friction: number; projected?: boolean; stress: Serie }
      • friction: number
      • Optional projected?: boolean
      • stress: Serie

    Returns { n1: Serie; n2: Serie } | Serie

generateDikes

  • generateDikes(__namedParameters: { projected?: boolean; stress: Serie }): Serie

  • Generate dikes from stress data. This is essentially the same as generateJoints. A dike is represented by its normal

    example
    const dikes = geop.generateDikes({
     stress: computedStressSerie,
     projected: false
})
    see

    generateJoints

    see

    JointData

    Parameters

    • __namedParameters: { projected?: boolean; stress: Serie }
      • Optional projected?: boolean
      • stress: Serie

    Returns Serie

generateJoints

  • generateJoints(__namedParameters: { projected?: boolean; stress: Serie }): Serie

  • Generate joints from stress data. A joint is represented by its normal

    example
    const joints = geop.generateJoints({
     stress: computedStressSerie,
     projected: true
})
    see

    JointData

    Parameters

    • __namedParameters: { projected?: boolean; stress: Serie }
      • Optional projected?: boolean
      • stress: Serie

    Returns Serie

generateStylolites

  • generateStylolites(__namedParameters: { projected?: boolean; stress: Serie }): Serie

  • Generate stylolites from stress data

    example
    const stylolites = geop.generateStylolites({
     stress: computedStressSerie,
     projected: false
})
    see

    [[StylolitesData]]

    Parameters

    • __namedParameters: { projected?: boolean; stress: Serie }
      • Optional projected?: boolean
      • stress: Serie

    Returns Serie

Geophysics Functions

generateInsar

  • generateInsar(__namedParameters: { LOS: vec.Vector3; displ: Serie }): Serie

  • Given a displacement field and a satellite line of sight, compute the corresponding Insar data.

    see

    InsarData

    example

    In the following example, the displacement field displ is computed using numerically, and the measuredInsar are the measures (observations). The size of displ is three times the size of insar.

    const computedInsar = generateInsar({displ, LOS: [0.01, -0.1, -0.9856]})
const measuredInsar = [...]

// Let use a loop instead of the Array.redure method
const cost = 0
for (let i=0; i<computedInsar.length; ++i) {
    cost += costInsar(computedInsar[i], measuredInsar[i])
}
cost /= computedInsar.length
    see

    Data

    Parameters

    • __namedParameters: { LOS: vec.Vector3; displ: Serie }
      • LOS: vec.Vector3
      • displ: Serie

        The displacement field as a flat array

    Returns Serie

Inversion Functions

Const monteCarlo

  • monteCarlo(params: InversionModel, n: number): InversionResult
  • brief

    A monte-carlo algorithm to perform an inversion.

    example
    const result = monteCarlo({
    data: [
        createData(GpsData, {
            dataframe: dataframe,
            measure  : 'gps',             // <--- loaded data
            compute  : ['u1', 'u2', 'u3'] // <--- 3 computed simulations
        }),
        createData(InsarData, {
            dataframe: dataframe,
            los      : LOS as math.Vector3,
            measure  : 'insar',           // <--- loaded data
            compute  : ['d1', 'd2', 'd3'] // <--- 3 computed simulations
        })
    ],
    alpha: {
        mapping: undefined,
        min    : [0,0,0], // therefore dim = 3
        max    : [1,1,1]
    }
}, 10000)
    see

    alphaMapping

    see

    AlphaParameters

    see

    Data

    Parameters

    • params: InversionModel

      The inversion parameters

    • n: number

      The number of simulations

    Returns InversionResult

Other Functions

Const cost

  • cost(data: Data | Data[], alpha: Alpha): number

  • Compute the associated cost to alpha given a Data or an array of Data.

    note

    When data is an array, returns the weighted cost. Otherwise, returns the cost (not multipled by the weight of the data).

    Parameters

    • data: Data | Data[]
    • alpha: Alpha

    Returns number

Const createData

  • createData(Type: any, param: any): Data

  • Convenient function to create a specific Data with its associated parameters

    see

    Data

    example
    const data = createData(InsarData, {
    dataframe: dfInsar,
    los: [0,0,1],
    measure: 'insar',
    compute: ['d1', 'd2', 'd3']
})

    Parameters

    • Type: any

      The type of data (class name)

    • param: any

      The parameters

    Returns Data

Const defaultMapping

  • defaultMapping(alpha: Alpha): Alpha

  • A default mapping for any Alpha. Basically it return the same alpha.

    see

    alphaMapping

    Parameters

    • alpha: Alpha

    Returns Alpha

generateFringes

  • generateFringes(serie: Serie, fringeSpacing: number): Serie

  • Generate fringes given fringe spacing.

    example
    const displ   = dataframe.series['Displ']
const fringes = generateFringes( generateInsar({displ, LOS: [0,0,-1]}), 0.01)

    Parameters

    • serie: Serie

      The serie with itemSize of 1

    • fringeSpacing: number

      The spacing of the fringes

    Returns Serie

    A new [[Serie]]

Const gradientPressureMapping

  • gradientPressureMapping(alpha: Alpha): Alpha

  • Transform the user-parameter-space [theta, Rh, RH, rockDensity, cavityDensity, shift1, shift2...] to the global one [Sxx, Sxy, Syy, Szz, density, shift1, shift2...], where theta is the orientation of the maximum principal horizontal stress according to the north, clock-wize and in [0..180], Rh is the ratio of Sigma_h/Sigma_v, RH is the ratio of Sigma_H/Sigma_v, and the shifts are the pressure shift of the cavity at z=0.

    Note that this regional stress and the pressure use the gradient and that you can provide as many shift pressures as necessary (as long as the number of linearly independent simulations are computed)

    see

    alphaMapping

    example
    // provide 2 pressure shifts
const alpha = GradientPressureMapping([45, 0.1, 0.2, 2300, 2200, -1e6, -1e7])

    Parameters

    • alpha: Alpha

      The user-define parameter space

    Returns Alpha

    [Sxx, Sxy, Syy, Szz, cavityDensity, shift1, shift2...]

Const simpleAndersonMapping

  • simpleAndersonMapping(alpha: Alpha): Alpha
  • brief

    Convert the regional Andersonian stress (theta, R) into the global CSys [xx, xy, yy]. Basically, this fonction convert a non-linear space into a linear one in order to be used by the superposition. This regional stress is not defined with gradient.

    see

    alphaMapping

    see

    publication
    Maerten, F., Madden, E. H., Pollard, D. D., & Maerten, L. (2016). Incorporating fault mechanics into inversions of aftershock data for the regional remote stress, with application to the 1992 Landers, California earthquake. Tectonophysics, 674, 52-64.

    Parameters

    • alpha: Alpha

      In the form [theta, R], with theta the angle in degrees of the maximum principal horizontal stress according to the north and clock wize and defined in the range [0..180], R the extended stress ratio in [0..3].

      For instance:

      • if R ∈ [0..1], then it is a normal fault regime
      • if R ∈ [1..2], then it is a strike slip fault regime
      • if R ∈ [2..3], then it is a reverse fault regime

    Returns Alpha
